paragraphs.text:
%md
### Silicon Valley Episode Dataset 

Welcome to a quick overview of Apache Spark with Sillicon Valley Episodes dataset. If you've never watched the Silicon Valley show you can learn more about it [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley_(TV_series)). 

In this notebook we will download the dataset (in JSON format) from an external github repository, ingest it into a Spark Dataset and perform basic analysis, filtering, and word count.

msg.data:
Silicon Valley Episode Dataset

Welcome to a quick overview of Apache Spark with Sillicon Valley Episodes dataset. If you've never watched the Silicon Valley show you can learn more about it here.

In this notebook we will download the dataset (in JSON format) from an external github repository, ingest it into a Spark Dataset and perform basic analysis, filtering, and word count.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### A few tips to run your Zeppelin Notebook:

msg.data: A few tips to run your Zeppelin Notebook:

paragraphs.title: How to run a paragraph?
paragraphs.text:
%md
To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook you can either click the `play` button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or simply press `Shift + Enter`.

msg.data: To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook you can either click the play button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or simply press Shift + Enter.

paragraphs.title: Some initial delay to be expected...
paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note**: The first time you run `spark.version` in the paragraph below, several services will initialize in the background. 
This may take **1~2 min** so please **be patient**.

Afterwards, each paragraph should run much more quickly since all the services will already be running.

msg.data:
Note: The first time you run spark.version in the paragraph below, several services will initialize in the background.
This may take 1~2 min so please be patient.

Afterwards, each paragraph should run much more quickly since all the services will already be running.

paragraphs.title: Verify Spark Version
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

spark.version

%md 
### Downloading and Moving the Silicon Valley Episodes Dataset to HDFS

msg.data: Downloading and Moving the Silicon Valley Episodes Dataset to HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%sh
echo {password.global} | kinit {user.global}
paragraphs.title: Required for Kerberos operations with user zeppelin
Download JSON data file
Copy file from Local Storage to HDFS (if available/supported)

paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls /tmp/{user.global}
paragraphs.title: Check that the file has been copied

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Datasets and DataFrames

To learn more about Dataset and DataFrames [Hands-On Tour of Apache Spark in 5 Minutes] (https://hortonworks.com/tutorial/hands-on-tour-of-apache-spark-in-5-minutes/#concepts).

msg.data:
Datasets and DataFrames

To learn more about Dataset and DataFrames Hands-On Tour of Apache Spark in 5 Minutes.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

path = "/tmp/{{ USER }}/svepisodes.json"
svEpisodes = spark.read.json(path)         # Create a DataFrame from JSON data (automatically infer schema and data types)
paragraphs.title: Load data into a Spark DataFrame

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

svEpisodes.printSchema()
paragraphs.title: Print DataFrame Schema
Data Description
paragraphs.text:
%angular
Column Name Description
1 Airdate Date when an episode was aired
2 Airstamp Timestamp when an episode was aired
3 Airtime Length of an actual episode airtime (no commercials)
4 Id Unique show id
5 Name Name of an episode
6 Number Episode number
7 Runtime Total length of an episode (including commercials)
8 Season Show season
9 Summary Brief summary of an episode
10 Url Url where more information is available online about an episode

msg.data:
Column Name Description
1 Airdate Date when an episode was aired
2 Airstamp Timestamp when an episode was aired
3 Airtime Length of an actual episode airtime (no commercials)
4 Id Unique show id
5 Name Name of an episode
6 Number Episode number
7 Runtime Total length of an episode (including commercials)
8 Season Show season
9 Summary Brief summary of an episode
10 Url Url where more information is available online about an episode

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

svEpisodes.show()
paragraphs.title: Show DataFrame Contents

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Is there a more interactive way to display query results?

Short answer, yes! The data displayed in the paragraph above isn't too interactive. To have a more dynamic experience, let's create a temporary (in-memory) view that we can query against and interact with the resulting data in a table or graph format. The temporary view will allow us to run SQL queries to get back results.

**Note** that the temporary view will reside in memory as long as the Spark session is alive.

msg.data:
Is there a more interactive way to display query results?

Short answer, yes! The data displayed in the paragraph above isn't too interactive. To have a more dynamic experience, let's create a temporary (in-memory) view that we can query against and interact with the resulting data in a table or graph format. The temporary view will allow us to run SQL queries to get back results.

Note that the temporary view will reside in memory as long as the Spark session is alive.

paragraphs.title: Create a Temporary View
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Creates a temporary view
svEpisodes.createOrReplaceTempView("svepisodes")

paragraphs.title: So now what?
paragraphs.text:
%md
#### So now what?
At this point we can run queries using a familiar SQL syntax against our newly registered `svepisodes` table. 

**Note** that although we are using a SQL syntax in the following paragraph it is translated and executed using the Spark engine with all the expected optimizations.

msg.data:
So now what?

At this point we can run queries using a familiar SQL syntax against our newly registered svepisodes table.

Note that although we are using a SQL syntax in the following paragraph it is translated and executed using the Spark engine with all the expected optimizations.

paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT * FROM svepisodes ORDER BY season, number

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: View Data in an Interactive Table Format

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Running a more complex SQL query on the uderlying table data

msg.data: Running a more complex SQL query on the uderlying table data

paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT count(1) AS TotalNumEpisodes FROM svepisodes

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Total Number of Episodes

paragraphs.text:
%sql 

SELECT season, count(number) as episodes FROM svepisodes GROUP BY season

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Number of Episodes per Season

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Word Count on Episode Summaries

Now let's perform a basic word-count on the summary column and find out which words occur most frequently. This should give us some indication on the popularity of certain characters and other relevant keywords in the context of the Sillicon Valley show.

msg.data:
Word Count on Episode Summaries

Now let's perform a basic word-count on the summary column and find out which words occur most frequently. This should give us some indication on the popularity of certain characters and other relevant keywords in the context of the Sillicon Valley show.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import *                        # Import additional helper functions

words = svEpisodes.select(explode(split(lower(col("summary"))," ")).alias("word")).filter(col("word") != "")
words.groupBy("word").count().orderBy("count", ascending=False).show()
paragraphs.title: Raw Word Count
Can we improve this?
paragraphs.text:
%md

As you can see there are plenty of stop words and punctuation marks that surface to the top. Let's clean this up a bit by creating a basic stop word list and a punctuation mark list that we'll use as basic filters before we aggregate and order the words again.

msg.data: As you can see there are plenty of stop words and punctuation marks that surface to the top. Let's clean this up a bit by creating a basic stop word list and a punctuation mark list that we'll use as basic filters before we aggregate and order the words again.

paragraphs.title: More Sophisticated Filtering
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

stopWords = {"a", "an", "to", "and", "the", "of", "in", "for", "by", "at"}      # Basic set of stop words
punctuationMarks = {"-", ",", ";", ":", ".", "?", "!"}                         # Basic set of punctuation marks

# Filter out stop words and punctuation marks

wordsFiltered = words.where(~col("word").isin(stopWords)).where(~col("word").isin(punctuationMarks))

%pyspark

wordsFiltered.groupBy("word").count().orderBy("count", ascending=False).show()
paragraphs.title: Improved Word Count
Note on the Results
paragraphs.text:
%md

Looks like Richard, Pied Piper, Dinesh, Erlich, Gavin and Jared are the key words in the Sillicon Valley show. Looks like a lot revolves around Richard!

msg.data: Looks like Richard, Pied Piper, Dinesh, Erlich, Gavin and Jared are the key words in the Sillicon Valley show. Looks like a lot revolves around Richard!

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Final Comments on Word Count

As you can see, there's more to do with our word list, e.g. Piper and Piper's should be counted as the same word. There's more, of course, however this is beyond the scope of this quick intro to Apache Spark.

msg.data:
Final Comments on Word Count

As you can see, there's more to do with our word list, e.g. Piper and Piper's should be counted as the same word. There's more, of course, however this is beyond the scope of this quick intro to Apache Spark.

%md
### Additional Resource

We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Cloudera Tutorials](http://cloudera.com/tutorials.html) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Cloudera Community](https://community.cloudera.com) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Apache Spark Documentation](https://spark.apache.org/documentation.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page](https://zeppelin.apache.org) - official Zeppelin web site.

msg.data:
<script type="text/javascript">
function runMarkdown() {
  
  let zeppelinApiUrl = "https://knguyen-spark-3-master0.knguyen.kfjr-x0dh.cloudera.site/knguyen-spark-3/cdp-proxy/zeppelin/api/";
  let baseUrl = "https://bshimel.github.io/ztest/notebooks/";

  function getNotebookInfo(notebookId) {
    $.ajax({
      url : zeppelinApiUrl + "notebook/" + notebookId,
      type : 'GET',
      dataType:'json',
      xhrFields: {
        withCredentials: true
      },
      success : function(data) {
        data.body.paragraphs.forEach(paragraph => {
          if (paragraph['text'].startsWith("%md") && !paragraph['results']) {
            runParagraph(notebookId, paragraph['id']);
          }
        });
      },
      error : function(request,error)
      {
          console.log("Request: "+JSON.stringify(request));
      }
    });
  }

  function runParagraph(notebookId, paragraphId) {
    $.ajax({
      url : zeppelinApiUrl + "notebook/job/" + notebookId + "/" + paragraphId,
      type : 'POST',
      dataType:'json',
      xhrFields: {
        withCredentials: true
      },
      success : function(data) {
        console.log("Ran " + notebookId + ", " + paragraphId);
      },
      error : function(request,error)
      {
          console.log("Request: "+JSON.stringify(request));
      }
    });
  }

  let pathArray = window.location.href.split('/');
  let notebookId = pathArray.pop();
  getNotebookInfo(notebookId);
}

runMarkdown();
</script>
